questions.question: Which of the following is a living thing?

answers.explanation: A car is a non-living, man-made object that does not grow or reproduce.
A dog grows, eats, moves on its own and can have puppies, so it is a living thing.
A rock does not grow, eat or move on its own.
A chair is a non-living, man-made object.

questions.question: All living things have basic needs. Which need is shared by every living thing on Earth?

answers.explanation: Every living thing needs water to survive.
Toys are not a basic need for survival.
Only some living things use electricity, and they can survive without it.
Chocolate is not a universal requirement for life.

questions.question: Name TWO characteristics that show something is living.

answers.content: Any two of: grows, eats/needs food, moves on its own/responds to light or touch, reproduces/makes more of itself.

questions.question: A sunflower slowly turns to face the Sun. This behaviour shows which characteristic of living things?

answers.explanation: Reproduction is making new plants or animals.
Turning toward light shows that the plant can move (slowly) and respond to its environment.
Sunflowers make food through photosynthesis, but turning toward light is not eating.
Sleeping is a rest state in many animals, not the main point here.

questions.question: On your school walk you noticed a puddle of water. Is the puddle living or non-living, and why?

answers.content: Non-living, because water does not grow, move on its own, eat or reproduce.

questions.question: Draw a simple Venn diagram. In the ‘Land’ circle, draw one living thing that lives on land. In the ‘Water’ circle, draw one living thing that lives in water. In the overlap, draw one living thing that can live on land AND in water.

answers.content: Teacher-marked drawing showing three appropriate organisms, e.g. dog (land), fish (water), frog (both).

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four basic needs that all animals must have to stay alive?

answers.explanation: Toys are enjoyable but an animal can survive without them; food, water and shelter are essential.

questions.question: Pets often rely on humans to meet their needs. Which need below do pets MOSTLY rely on humans for?

answers.explanation: Most household pets cannot build an appropriate shelter themselves and depend on people to provide one.

questions.question: Give TWO reasons why water is important for animals.

answers.content: Sample answer: Water helps animals digest food and keeps their bodies at the right temperature.

questions.question: Draw a pet and label at least THREE of its basic needs (for example: food, water, shelter, air, exercise).

answers.content: Student’s labelled drawing includes at least three correct needs.

questions.question: During the class pet-shop activity, what material did students use to model their chosen pet?

answers.explanation: The lesson instructions said to ‘use playdough or modelling clay to make a model of a pet.’

questions.question: Which two things did students learn that plants need to stay alive?

answers.explanation: The lesson centred on observing that watering a wilted plant and giving another plant light helped them grow; both water and sunlight were identified as essential.
Milk is not a basic plant need discussed in the lesson.
Chocolate is not required by plants.
Ice is not mentioned; water in liquid form is what plants need.

questions.question: In the photo sequence, why did the droopy plant become healthy again?

answers.explanation: The time-lapse showed the wilted plant recovering immediately after being given water.

answers.content: It was moved to a colder room
answers.explanation: Temperature change was not shown in the activity.
No fertiliser was added; only water changed.
Music was not part of the experiment.

questions.question: During the "Plants and Light" video, one cup was covered so the plant did NOT receive _____.

answers.explanation: The cup was placed in darkness; both plants were watered, but only one received light.
Both plants were watered equally.
Both cups contained soil.
Both cups were planted with seeds.

questions.question: Give one sign that tells you a plant is NOT healthy.

answers.content: Leaves look droopy / wilted / brown / yellow
answers.explanation: Students compared a wilted plant with a healthy one; droopy or discoloured leaves indicate poor health.

questions.question: Why is water important for a plant? (Write one reason.)

answers.content: Water helps move nutrients and keeps the plant firm / is needed for photosynthesis
answers.explanation: Teacher reading notes explained water’s role in transporting nutrients and supporting photosynthesis.

questions.question: Draw a young plant showing the two things it needs most to grow. Include labels.

answers.content: Teacher rubric: picture includes (a) plant (b) source of water (raindrops, watering can etc.) (c) source of sunlight (sun rays, lamp). Full marks require both needs labelled.

questions.question: During photosynthesis plants use sunlight, water and __________.

answers.explanation: Teacher reading notes listed air (carbon dioxide) as a requirement for photosynthesis.
Oxygen is released, not used, in photosynthesis.
Sugar (glucose) is produced, not consumed.
Soil provides nutrients but is not a reactant in photosynthesis.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a basic need for plants mentioned in the lesson?

answers.explanation: Space for roots and air circulation was included in teacher notes.
Video games are unrelated to plant survival and were not discussed.
Water is essential.
Sunlight is essential.

questions.question: Which of these objects does NOT need water to survive?

answers.explanation: A rock is non-living and therefore has no need for water.

questions.question: Most animals get water into their bodies by using their _____.

answers.explanation: Animals lap, sip or suck water through their mouths.

questions.question: Name the part of a plant that first takes in water from the ground.

answers.explanation: Roots absorb water and then pass it up the stem.

questions.question: During the coloured-water experiment, which flower is likely to show coloured petals after one day?

answers.content: The flower standing in plain water
The flower standing in coloured water
answers.explanation: The coloured water travels up the stem and tints the petals.

questions.question: Give one reason why people need water.

answers.content: to drink / stay alive / help our bodies work / keep cool / digestion / cleaning (any valid reason)
answers.explanation: Humans rely on water for many life-supporting processes such as drinking, digestion and temperature control.

questions.question: Draw what you think the old sailor is looking at when he says, “Water, water, everywhere, not a drop to drink!”

answers.explanation: Student’s drawing should show lots of undrinkable seawater (e.g. an ocean scene) to demonstrate understanding that salty ocean water is not suitable for drinking.
